text: The Waianae Sugar Company, founded in 1878, was the first major sugar plantation on Oahu, Hawaii. == History == In 1878, Judge Hermann Widemann planted his first crop in Wai'anae, eleven years before the creation of the Oahu Railway and Land Company, and seventeen years before the OR&L; would reach the sugar mill. Waianae Sugar Company's plantation cultivated land in three valleys, Makaha, Lualualei, and Wai'anae. Having a narrow gauge railway line, it was the only sugar plantation on the island whose tracks could not connect to the OR&L;'s tracks. Despite struggles for water, this company lasted 69 years, closing down in 1947, the same year as the Oahu Railway's closure. By 1890, sugar cane was planted on 600 acres with a yield of 2,500 tons. The company had 350 workers and three locomotives to transport the cane over 12 miles of narrow gauge track. == Locomotives == The first locomotive was imported from John Fowler & Co. at Leeds, England. It had to be disassembled and re-assembled to get it ashore. Only then it was noted that it did not match the narrow gauge track. The undercarriage had to be dismantled, machined to size, and then commissioned. == References == Category:Sugar companies of the United States Category:Defunct companies based in Hawaii Category:Waianae Range Category:Transportation in Honolulu County, Hawaii Category:Defunct Hawaii railroads Category:Sugar mill railways Category:Narrow gauge railroads in Hawaii Category:2 ft 6 in gauge railways in the United States Category:Food and drink companies established in 1878 Category:Food and drink companies disestablished in 1947 Category:Railway companies established in 1878 Category:Railway companies disestablished in 1947 Category:1878 establishments in Hawaii Category:1947 disestablishments in Hawaii
